<td style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;vertical-align: top" valign="top">

<td class="editors_note" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding: 0px 40px 16px 40px; border-left: 2px solid #353535; border-right: 2px solid #353535; border-bottom: 2px solid #353535; border-collapse: collapse; border-radius: 0px 0px 10px 10px;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<div>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Good morning </strong>and welcome to a special Halloween edition of the Morning Boo.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">To kick off the festivities, I huddled up with the Brew writers to compile a list of the 10 types of people you will encounter at <em>any</em> Halloween party:</p>
<ol style="line-height:22px">
<li><span>The person who thinks they’re clever with their “cereal killer” pun costume</span></li>
<li><span>Banana suit guy</span></li>
<li><span>Someone who spent a lot of money on an intricate costume four years ago and keeps re-wearing it</span></li>
<li><span>A couple as a hunter and a deer</span></li>
<li><span>Sexy [insert prominent figure from the news]</span></li>
<li><span>The person who takes Halloween so seriously you’re not even sure if that’s fake blood</span></li>
<li><span>Football jersey cop-out guy</span></li>
<li><span>The six people who dressed up as the main character of a recent Netflix documentary</span></li>
<li><span>The person who has to explain their costume to everyone because it’s super niche</span></li>
<li><span>Your friend's new boyfriend who is dressed too scary and is making a terrible first impression</span></li>
</ol>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Which person are you? I'm a shameless football jersey cop-out guy. Sorry, just who I am. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;font-family:flood-std, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;font-size:16px;font-weight:500">—Neal Freyman</p>
</div>
</div>

<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/29/icebreakers-with-haunted-house-realtor-marianne-bornhoft?email={{profile.email}}" style="color:#353535!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" target="_blank">
Icebreakers With...Haunted House Realtor Marianne Bornhoft
</a>
</h1>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/29/icebreakers-with-haunted-house-realtor-marianne-bornhoft?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Marianne Bornhoft" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/00a233bc0574239501f2d7934918f7ae06e0873c-800x533.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;"></p>
</a>
<small>
<em>Marianne Bornhoft</em>
</small>
<div>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Marianne Bornhoft is a <a href="https://twitter.com/spokanehouse?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">real estate agent</a> in Spokane, Washington, with a background in selling some of the area’s most haunted homes. In real-estate speak, “stigmatized” is the term for homes rumored to contain a Casper that isn’t memory foam, and the category includes on-site murders, deaths, and a whole series of unfortunate events.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">We chatted with Bornhoft about this tricky business, and it was a real treat.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>States have different rules around whether realtors are required to tell prospective buyers that a home is stigmatized. What do you think those rules <em>should</em> be?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">In Washington state, we do not have to disclose rapes, murders, suicides, illegal gang activity, religious persecution, crime statistics, the list goes on and on. In addition to that, we do not have to disclose if there was ever the presence of a ghost. It's really up to the individual who is researching the property...which personally I like.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">But there’s a difference between murders on-site versus ghosts. Honestly, as a realtor, I think we <em>should</em> disclose that there was a murder on-site or if there were dead bodies buried on the property.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>You recently sold a home rumored to have a <a href="https://www.legendsofamerica.com/wa-patsyclark/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">friendly ghost</a>. What’s the difference between selling a home with a friendly ghost vs. one with an unfriendly ghost?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">It's all about perception. I have been in homes where someone has recently died, homes where a body has been recently found, homes where we have found secret rooms and bomb shelters. I have been in homes with rumors of ghosts and I have personally had very interesting experiences. And I have witnesses for that.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Nothing has ever been negative toward me, but I have had the interesting experience of unexplained phenomena that you just can’t make up.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Go on...</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">For example, in the Polly Judd house, which is a very famous house that had three suicides in it, when I did that open house, I literally had hundreds of people come by and tell me their stories. The spirits could not let that house go.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">After I had pictures taken to sell the house, I'm looking at this picture of the dining room, and the chandelier had a shadow behind it on the wall that was three upside down crosses...which is not a very good sign. At that open house, I was standing in the living room telling [my husband on the phone] a story and all of a sudden the chandelier, the one in the picture, started moving. So I turned on FaceTime to show him that it was moving and that there was no wind. Then behind me, the door to the bathroom shut on its own.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">I couldn't get anyone to come and look at it after that, the market was terrible. So I kind of did a cleanse. And literally the next day I got a call from someone saying, “Hey, we want to show it. We love it. We're making an offer now.”</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Would you live in a haunted house?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">100%. I'm an antique dealer. I’m a historical home specialist, and I believe that we do not own homes. We are caretakers of the past. So it would be an honor and a privilege to be in a historical home at whatever level.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>This interview has been edited and condensed for clarity.</em></p>
</div>

<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/29/make-it-work-when-an-old-co-worker-asks-to-catch-up?email={{profile.email}}" style="color:#353535!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" target="_blank">
When an Old Co-worker Asks You to "Catch Up"
</a>
</h1>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/29/make-it-work-when-an-old-co-worker-asks-to-catch-up?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Make it work image " style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/7b6de1bb891bb0dd9e289abb0a591582a5da30e6-1503x603.png?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;"></p>
</a>
<small>
<em></em>
</small>
<div>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>Each week, our workplace whisperer Shane Loughnane answers a reader-submitted question about work in 2021. Anything bothering you at work? <a href="https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Bb6753cbd?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Ask Shane here</a>.</em></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>I recently switched jobs, and an old co-worker keeps reaching out to schedule time to “catch up” with me. We’re not very close and it feels like they’re only reaching out because I’ve landed a job at a prestigious firm and they want an in. I don’t mind chatting with them, but if they outright ask for a referral, how do I politely turn them down?—Anonymous</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Sure, Halloween can be scary, but is there anything spookier than your email inbox? Deadlines and updates and syncs (oh my). Just when you think you’re safe, an ominous request from an old co-worker reaches out and grabs your leg. Scary stuff.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">While it’s always great to pay it forward, you are wise to be judicious with your referral capital, as your own brand, by extension, is on the line. So when your ex-colleague pops the question, be honest and direct. While it may be tempting to decline based on your current lack of tenure, for example, how will that play when they ask again in six months? If you’re simply not familiar with them or comfortable enough with their work to serve as a reference, your best bet is to be upfront about it now.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">In the meantime, consider if there’s anything else you’d be willing to do to help them out. Is passing along their resume without necessarily referring them an option? Perhaps you could offer to keep an eye out for other opportunities, or recommend networking events within the industry. If nothing else, providing some insight on what made you more attractive to your new firm may be a gesture they appreciate.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Good luck—and if anyone reading this emerges from tonight with a candy surplus, we should totally plan to “catch up” soon.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>Have a question about work you want to ask Shane? <a href="https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Cb6753cbd?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Write in here</a>. And if you’re super interested in how people deal with people, <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/hr/subscribe?utm_campaign=hr_in_morningbrew_sundays&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=crosspromo" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">check out HR Brew</a>.</em></p>
</div>

<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;word-break: keep-all; word-wrap: normal; text-align: center; text-transform: uppercase; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 16px; line-height: 18px; color: #353535; padding: 0px; margin: 0px;">
ANALYSIS
</p>
</td>
<td width="33%" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">
<div style="text-align: center; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #2b9295, #1c7ff2); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;">

<tr class="">
<td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/29/the-occult-is-having-a-moment?email={{profile.email}}" style="color:#353535!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" target="_blank">
The Occult Is Having a Moment
</a>
</h1>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/29/the-occult-is-having-a-moment?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="Hands move across a ouija board" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=353 src="https://images.morningbrew.com/gif/2021-10-29/image-87e1df43cdee41f0e693d76c53ae63f4635a1ff7-500x263-gif/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="Hands move across a ouija board" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://images.morningbrew.com/gif/2021-10-29/image-87e1df43cdee41f0e693d76c53ae63f4635a1ff7-500x263-gif/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;"></p>
</a>
<small>
<em>Giphy</em>
</small>
<div>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Emo kids of the early aughts, step aside: The next generation has one-upped you on the freaking-out-parents scale. Witchcraft has risen in popularity during the pandemic, particularly on TikTok. Actually all occult practices—including astrology and tarot—have seen a big bump in interest since March of last year.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Online mentions of the occult increased an average of <a href="https://www.brandwatch.com/blog/react-covid-19-occult/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">4% every week</a> since March 2020, when Covid-19 shutdowns started to sweep the nation, despite trending down in the three weeks beforehand. Astrology and ghost mentions also swelled, and the tone of all these occult-themed conversations switched from mostly negative → positive, per Brandwatch.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">When it comes to getting witchy, TikTok is the new Platform 9 3/4:</p>
<ul style="line-height:22px">
<li><span>The TikTok hashtag #WitchTok has 20.5 billion views.</span></li>
<li>
<span>Top witch influencers have tons of followers: Frankie Anne (</span><span><a href="https://www.tiktok.com/@chaoticwitchaunt?lang=en" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">@chaoticwitchaunt</a></span><span>) shares her life as a witch with 1.3 million followers and Val Louiee (</span><span><a href="https://www.tiktok.com/@idiotmantra?is_copy_url=1&is_from_webapp=v1" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">@idiotmantra</a></span><span>) reads tarot cards and sends “signs” to her 75.6k.</span>
</li>
<li><span>And if you take a quick scroll, you’ll see the content isn’t Harry Potter fan edits. It’s witches teaching spells and young TikTokers trying to manifest their dream lives, selves, and lovers by commenting “claiming this” underneath videos.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">The spells are at least summoning one thing: money. “Psychic services,” which encompass palm and aura readings, astrology, mediating with the other side, and more, is an industry worth $2.2 billion in the US. It's expanded about one-half a percent every year since 2016 and is expected to <a href="https://www.ibisworld.com/united-states/market-research-reports/psychic-services-industry/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">more than double</a> that rate, with 2.6% growth this year alone.</p>
<h2 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">What’s going on?</h2>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><a href="https://www.tiktok.com/@officialmadamadam?is_copy_url=1&is_from_webapp=v1" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Adam Wethington</a>, who reads tarot on TikTok to 1.5 million followers, <a href="https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/2021/10/14/tiktok-witchtok-has-billions-views-witches-explain-why/6102147001/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">told USA Today</a>, “WitchTok content is so relevant right now because we learned last year we can't control (things). ...Many of us are looking inward.” And in times of uncertainty, people have historically looked <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2021/08/19/us/witchtok-astrology-covid-19-pandemic-trnd/index.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">to the occult</a> to “get some kind of answer about the future...something that’s reassuring in some way,” Yale psychology professor James Alcock explained to CNN.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Not to mention that the aesthetic of occult items (think: crystals, tarot cards) are Urban Outfitters-esque eye candy, and with sparse G-Cals, people spent record amounts of time seeking inspiration on social media last year.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Zoom out: </strong>Baking banana bread, buying a Peloton, learning to knit...the list of ways people tried to cope with the pandemic is endless. A little “double, double toil and trouble” is just one method, regardless of whether it’s your personal cauldron of tea.—<em>JW</em></p>
</div>

<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/29/open-house-not-a-haunted-house-if-that-s-what-you-re-thinking?email={{profile.email}}" style="color:#353535!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" target="_blank">
Open House
</a>
</h1>
<div>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Welcome to Open House, the only newsletter section that isn’t giving in to any Halloween hullabaloo and will be doing things completely normal. No ghosts, ghouls, or monsters. We’ll give you a few facts about a listing and you try to guess the price.</p>
<img class="img-responsive" src="https://images.morningbrew.com/gif/2021-10-29/image-b0819b33adc5dc2f2ff8a7f353dc8cdb45e50e1b-900x563-gif/conjuring.gif" alt="House that inspired The Conjuring movie" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;width:100% !important"><p><em>Blueflash Photography for Mott & Chace/Sotheby’s International Realty</em></p><p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">That was a trick—today’s <a href="https://robbreport.com/shelter/homes-for-sale/the-conjuring-house-1234637722/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">home</a> is obviously haunted. So haunted, in fact, that it’s the inspiration for the 2013 movie, <em>The Conjuring</em>. The current owners of the 3,109-square-foot farmhouse in Burrillville, Rhode Island, say their experiences with the spirits haven’t been quite to the movie’s level, but there’s definitely <em>something</em> in the house. Amenities include:</p>
<ul style="line-height:22px">
<li><span>3 beds, 1.5 baths</span></li>
<li><span>8.5 secluded acres of land</span></li>
<li><span>Spirit of Bathsheba Sherman, rumored witch who was buried in the cemetery four miles away</span></li>
<li><span>Vintage wood fireplace</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">How much to live your<em> Ghost Adventures</em> fantasy?</p>
</div>

padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv style=\"font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;\"\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/29/icebreakers-with-haunted-house-realtor-marianne-bornhoft?email={{profile.email}}\" style=\"color:#353535!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\" target=\"_blank\"\u003e\nIcebreakers With...Haunted House Realtor Marianne Bornhoft\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/29/icebreakers-with-haunted-house-realtor-marianne-bornhoft?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" style=\"text-decoration:none; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Marianne Bornhoft\" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/00a233bc0574239501f2d7934918f7ae06e0873c-800x533.jpg?w=670\u0026q=70\u0026auto=format\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003eMarianne Bornhoft\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eMarianne Bornhoft is a \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/spokanehouse?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereal estate agent\u003c/a\u003e in Spokane, Washington, with a background in selling some of the area’s most haunted homes. In real-estate speak, “stigmatized” is the term for homes rumored to contain a Casper that isn’t memory foam, and the category includes on-site murders, deaths, and a whole series of unfortunate events.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWe chatted with Bornhoft about this tricky business, and it was a real treat.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eStates have different rules around whether realtors are required to tell prospective buyers that a home is stigmatized. What do you think those rules \u003cem\u003eshould\u003c/em\u003e be?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIn Washington state, we do not have to disclose rapes, murders, suicides, illegal gang activity, religious persecution, crime statistics, the list goes on and on. In addition to that, we do not have to disclose if there was ever the presence of a ghost. It's really up to the individual who is researching the property...which personally I like.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eBut there’s a difference between murders on-site versus ghosts. Honestly, as a realtor, I think we \u003cem\u003eshould\u003c/em\u003e disclose that there was a murder on-site or if there were dead bodies buried on the property.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eYou recently sold a home rumored to have a \u003ca href=\"https://www.legendsofamerica.com/wa-patsyclark/?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efriendly ghost\u003c/a\u003e. What’s the difference between selling a home with a friendly ghost vs. one with an unfriendly ghost?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIt's all about perception. I have been in homes where someone has recently died, homes where a body has been recently found, homes where we have found secret rooms and bomb shelters. I have been in homes with rumors of ghosts and I have personally had very interesting experiences. And I have witnesses for that.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eNothing has ever been negative toward me, but I have had the interesting experience of unexplained phenomena that you just can’t make up.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGo on...\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eFor example, in the Polly Judd house, which is a very famous house that had three suicides in it, when I did that open house, I literally had hundreds of people come by and tell me their stories. The spirits could not let that house go.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eAfter I had pictures taken to sell the house, I'm looking at this picture of the dining room, and the chandelier had a shadow behind it on the wall that was three upside down crosses...which is not a very good sign. At that open house, I was standing in the living room telling [my husband on the phone] a story and all of a sudden the chandelier, the one in the picture, started moving. So I turned on FaceTime to show him that it was moving and that there was no wind. Then behind me, the door to the bathroom shut on its own.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eI couldn't get anyone to come and look at it after that, the market was terrible. So I kind of did a cleanse. And literally the next day I got a call from someone saying, “Hey, we want to show it. We love it. We're making an offer now.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWould you live in a haunted house?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e100%. I'm an antique dealer. I’m a historical home specialist, and I believe that we do not own homes. We are caretakers of the past. So it would be an honor and a privilege to be in a historical home at whatever level.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eThis interview has been edited and condensed for clarity.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: collapse\" width=\"100%\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding-top: 12px\"\u003e\n\u003ca rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer.php?u=https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/29/icebreakers-with-haunted-house-realtor-marianne-bornhoft\u0026utm_source=facebook_share\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: inline-block; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv style=\"font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;\"\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/29/make-it-work-when-an-old-co-worker-asks-to-catch-up?email={{profile.email}}\" style=\"color:#353535!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\" target=\"_blank\"\u003e\nWhen an Old Co-worker Asks You to \"Catch Up\" \n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/29/make-it-work-when-an-old-co-worker-asks-to-catch-up?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" style=\"text-decoration:none; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Make it work image \" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/7b6de1bb891bb0dd9e289abb0a591582a5da30e6-1503x603.png?w=670\u0026q=70\u0026auto=format\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eEach week, our workplace whisperer Shane Loughnane answers a reader-submitted question about work in 2021. Anything bothering you at work? \u003ca href=\"https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Bb6753cbd?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eAsk Shane here\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eI recently switched jobs, and an old co-worker keeps reaching out to schedule time to “catch up” with me. We’re not very close and it feels like they’re only reaching out because I’ve landed a job at a prestigious firm and they want an in. I don’t mind chatting with them, but if they outright ask for a referral, how do I politely turn them down?—Anonymous\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eSure, Halloween can be scary, but is there anything spookier than your email inbox? Deadlines and updates and syncs (oh my). Just when you think you’re safe, an ominous request from an old co-worker reaches out and grabs your leg. Scary stuff.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWhile it’s always great to pay it forward, you are wise to be judicious with your referral capital, as your own brand, by extension, is on the line. So when your ex-colleague pops the question, be honest and direct. While it may be tempting to decline based on your current lack of tenure, for example, how will that play when they ask again in six months? If you’re simply not familiar with them or comfortable enough with their work to serve as a reference, your best bet is to be upfront about it now.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIn the meantime, consider if there’s anything else you’d be willing to do to help them out. Is passing along their resume without necessarily referring them an option? Perhaps you could offer to keep an eye out for other opportunities, or recommend networking events within the industry. If nothing else, providing some insight on what made you more attractive to your new firm may be a gesture they appreciate.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eGood luck—and if anyone reading this emerges from tonight with a candy surplus, we should totally plan to “catch up” soon.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eHave a question about work you want to ask Shane? \u003ca href=\"https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Cb6753cbd?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eWrite in here\u003c/a\u003e. padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv style=\"font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;\"\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/29/the-occult-is-having-a-moment?email={{profile.email}}\" style=\"color:#353535!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\" target=\"_blank\"\u003e\nThe Occult Is Having a Moment\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/29/the-occult-is-having-a-moment?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" style=\"text-decoration:none; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003c!--[if mso]\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Hands move across a ouija board\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" height=353 src=\"https://images.morningbrew.com/gif/2021-10-29/image-87e1df43cdee41f0e693d76c53ae63f4635a1ff7-500x263-gif/giphy.gif\"\u003e\n\u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003c!--[if !mso]\u003e--\u003e\u003c!-- --\u003e\n\u003cimg class=\"story-header-image\" alt=\"Hands move across a ouija board\" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" src=\"https://images.morningbrew.com/gif/2021-10-29/image-87e1df43cdee41f0e693d76c53ae63f4635a1ff7-500x263-gif/giphy.gif\"\u003e\n\u003c!--\u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003eGiphy\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eEmo kids of the early aughts, step aside: The next generation has one-upped you on the freaking-out-parents scale. Witchcraft has risen in popularity during the pandemic, particularly on TikTok. Actually all occult practices—including astrology and tarot—have seen a big bump in interest since March of last year.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eOnline mentions of the occult increased an average of \u003ca href=\"https://www.brandwatch.com/blog/react-covid-19-occult/?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e4% every week\u003c/a\u003e since March 2020, when Covid-19 shutdowns started to sweep the nation, despite trending down in the three weeks beforehand. Astrology and ghost mentions also swelled, and the tone of all these occult-themed conversations switched from mostly negative → positive, per Brandwatch.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWhen it comes to getting witchy, TikTok is the new Platform 9 3/4:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"line-height:22px\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe TikTok hashtag #WitchTok has 20.5 billion views.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eTop witch influencers have tons of followers: Frankie Anne (\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/@chaoticwitchaunt?lang=en\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e@chaoticwitchaunt\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e) shares her life as a witch with 1.3 million followers and Val Louiee (\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/@idiotmantra?is_copy_url=1\u0026is_from_webapp=v1\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e@idiotmantra\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e) reads tarot cards and sends “signs” to her 75.6k.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAnd if you take a quick scroll, you’ll see the content isn’t Harry Potter fan edits. It’s witches teaching spells and young TikTokers trying to manifest their dream lives, selves, and lovers by commenting “claiming this” underneath videos.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThe spells are at least summoning one thing: money. “Psychic services,” which encompass palm and aura readings, astrology, mediating with the other side, and more, is an industry worth $2.2 billion in the US. It's expanded about one-half a percent every year since 2016 and is expected to \u003ca href=\"https://www.ibisworld.com/united-states/market-research-reports/psychic-services-industry/?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emore than double\u003c/a\u003e that rate, with 2.6% growth this year alone.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003eWhat’s going on?\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/@officialmadamadam?is_copy_url=1\u0026is_from_webapp=v1\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eAdam Wethington\u003c/a\u003e, who reads tarot on TikTok to 1.5 million followers, \u003ca href=\"https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/2021/10/14/tiktok-witchtok-has-billions-views-witches-explain-why/6102147001/?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etold USA Today\u003c/a\u003e, “WitchTok content is so relevant right now because we learned last year we can't control (things). ...Many of us are looking inward.” And in times of uncertainty, people have historically looked \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2021/08/19/us/witchtok-astrology-covid-19-pandemic-trnd/index.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eto the occult\u003c/a\u003e to “get some kind of answer about the future...something that’s reassuring in some way,” Yale psychology professor James Alcock explained to CNN.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eNot to mention that the aesthetic of occult items (think: crystals, tarot cards) are Urban Outfitters-esque eye candy, and with sparse G-Cals, people spent record amounts of time seeking inspiration on social media last year.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eBaking banana bread, buying a Peloton, learning to knit...the list of ways people tried to cope with the pandemic is endless.
